noun.description: The branches of a tree; trees collectively. Now archaic and rare.
Cultural Anthropology. In Polynesian ethnography: a cognatic descent group; a system of ranked descent groups.

adjective.description: Of clothes, fabrics, etc.: adorned with a representation of branches or foliage.

origin: Middle English (in an earlier sense). From Anglo-Norman and Old French, Middle French ramage (French † ramage) (of a bird, especially a young hunting bird) untrained, wild, (more generally) of the trees, (of a forest) bushy, (of an animal) wild, untamed from ram branch + -age. Compare post-classical Latin ramageus, ramagius (in falconry) wild, untamed, having left the nest. Compare Old Occitan ramatge.
